prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. Find the last two digits of the following sum: $$5! + 10! + 15! + \cdots + 100!$$
solution: Since for all $n \ge 10$, $n!$ has (at least) two factors of 5, we know that $n!$ will end in two zeros.  Therefore, if $n\ge 10$, then $n!$ contributes nothing to the last two digits of the sum. So we need only compute $5! = 120$, and hence our answer is $\boxed{20}$.
gpt_response:
To find the last two digits of the sum, we can just look at the last two digits of each factorial number and add them up! 

Let's start by finding the last two digits of each factorial number:
- $5!$ = 120, so the last two digits are 20
- $10!$ = 3,628,800, so the last two digits are 00
- $15!$ = 1,307,674,368,000, so the last two digits are 00
- $20!$ = 2,432,902,008,176,640,000, so the last two digits are 00

From this we can see that all the factorials have two zeros at the end, so when we add them together, the sum will also end in two zeros!

So the last two digits of the sum $5! + 10! + 15! + \cdots + 100!$ is 00!
